G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: The amount of damages reasonably anticipated to be recovered by Plaintiff exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, and therefore is within the jurisdiction of the Massachusetts Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 and G.L. c. 223, § 2 because the cause of action arose in Worcester County and the Property where the incident occurred is located at 45 Maple Street, Worcester, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 and G.L. c. 223, § 2 because the cause of action arose in Worcester County and the Property where the incident occurred is located at 45 Maple Street, Worcester, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, landowners and possessors of land owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care in the circumstances, including with respect to conditions of snow and ice.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award Plaintiff pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, landowners and possessors of land owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care in the circumstances, including with respect to conditions of snow and ice.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the duty owed by landowners/possessors for snow and ice conditions and explicitly states that they owe lawful visitors the same general duty of reasonable care that applies to all other hazards. The court abolishes the prior natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and confirms that the governing Massachusetts rule is a duty of reasonable care in the circumstances toward lawful visitors with respect to hazards from snow and ice.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt:
“We now abolish the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, and apply to all hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation of reasonable care that a property owner owes to lawful visitors regarding all other hazards.”
...
“We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances….’”

Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.raw_text: Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc., 471 Mass. 679, 683–84 (2015)
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.proposition: The duty of reasonable care requires a property owner who undertakes to clear snow and ice from areas of pedestrian traffic to do so in a manner that does not unreasonably increase the risk of harm and to act reasonably in light of known or reasonably foreseeable hazards.
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The case discusses the general tort principle that landowners owe a duty of reasonable care to protect invitees from unsafe conditions, and it specifically focuses on the mode of operation doctrine and notice in a nightclub slip-and-fall context. It does not address snow and ice removal or articulate any special duty regarding how a property owner who undertakes to clear snow and ice must do so. The snow-and-ice notion appears only in a brief analogy to Papadopoulos, not as a holding or rule in this case, so this opinion does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant suggests that applying the mode of operation approach outside of the self-service context will result in a regime of strict liability. We again disagree. The law demands reasonable care, not perfection. See Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 343, 344. … Irrespective of the particular mode of operation involved, the plaintiff bears the burden of establishing that the defendant failed to exercise reasonable care in protecting its patrons from the unsafe conditions facilitated by its mode of operation.”

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.proposition: Defendant, having actual control over and having undertaken to clear the sidewalk and create a narrow shoveled path, owed Plaintiff a duty to use reasonable care in clearing, treating, and maintaining that path, and in warning of any dangerous condition thereon.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.support_reasoning: The case concerns a landowner’s duty to remedy an open and obvious danger created by placing a trampoline next to a shallow pool. It does not involve snow or ice, sidewalks, or the clearing/creation of a shoveled path, nor does it discuss a duty specifically in the context of undertaking snow or ice removal. While it broadly affirms that a landowner who creates and maintains a dangerous condition may owe a duty to remedy it despite its obviousness, it does not establish the more specific sidewalk‑clearing duty described in the proposition.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.relevant_excerpt: “Section 343A thus instructs that although a duty to warn of an open and obvious danger would be superfluous because an open and obvious danger provides its own warning, a landowner is not relieved from remedying that danger where he knows or has reason to know that lawful entrants may not heed the warning for a variety of reasons, including their own failure to exercise reasonable care. … In cases where a negligent failure to warn is not the only viable theory of negligence … the landowner may still owe a duty to the lawful entrant to remedy an open and obvious danger.”

Schultz v. Grogean, 406 Mass. 364, 366\u.proposition: Defendant’s failure to reasonably maintain the sidewalk and the path, despite the foreseeable risk of harm and actual notice of the dangerous condition, constitutes a breach of the duty of reasonable care recognized under Massachusetts law.
Schultz v. Grogean, 406 Mass. 364, 366\u.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns wrongful death damages and whether parents of an emancipated adult child may recover consortium-type damages as next of kin under G.L. c. 229, §§ 1–2. It does not address premises liability, sidewalk or path maintenance, foreseeability of harm, notice of dangerous conditions, or breach of duty of reasonable care. Therefore, it does not support the cited proposition about a defendant’s failure to maintain a sidewalk or path under Massachusetts law.
Schultz v. Grogean, 406 Mass. 364, 366\u.relevant_excerpt: “We therefore conclude that G. L. c. 229, §§ 1 and 2, permits parents of a deceased adult unmarried child, as next of kin, to recover for those elements of damages set forth in the wrongful death statute.”

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also constitutes an unreasonable failure to protect foreseeable entrants, including delivery personnel such as Plaintiff, from a known or reasonably knowable hazard, in violation of the general duty of care owed by property owners and occupiers.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurrence focused on criticizing the continued use of the trespasser/licensee/invitee classifications; it does not discuss a specific duty to protect foreseeable entrants such as delivery personnel from known hazards. While the larger Mounsey decision is generally about broadening occupiers’ duty of care, this short passage neither articulates nor applies the stated proposition about an unreasonable failure to protect foreseeable entrants. Thus, based solely on this text, the citation does not clearly support the specific duty proposition claimed.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that “trespassers” stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential.

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also constitutes an unreasonable failure to protect foreseeable entrants, including delivery personnel such as Plaintiff, from a known or reasonably knowable hazard, in violation of the general duty of care owed by property owners and occupiers.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that the defendant’s conduct is an unreasonable failure to protect foreseeable entrants (including delivery personnel) from a known or knowable hazard, based on the general duty of care of property owners. Davis v. Westwood Group reiterates the general rule that landowners owe reasonable care to lawful visitors, but the holding is that the defendant *did not* owe a duty to protect the plaintiff from hazards on the adjacent state highway and specifically rejects expanding landowner duties in that way. Thus, the case undercuts, rather than supports, using a broad duty theory to require protection from off-premises hazards like the one described in the proposition.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors… This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware… In this case, Westwood did not fail to exercise reasonable care in the use of its land, nor was there any condition on its land that created an unreasonable risk to users of Route 1A.”

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 639 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: The harm to Plaintiff was the very kind of harm that makes Defendant’s conduct negligent and was reasonably foreseeable in light of Defendant’s knowledge of the icy condition and the common risk of slips and falls arising from untreated snow and ice on pedestrian pathways in winter.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The concurring opinion explicitly agrees that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. That is the opposite of the claimed proposition, which asserts that the harm was the very kind that made the defendant’s conduct negligent and was reasonably foreseeable. Thus, this case does not support the proposition and instead undermines it.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: I concur in the view that "[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence." Ante at 640-641.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.proposition: The harm to Plaintiff was the very kind of harm that makes Defendant’s conduct negligent and was reasonably foreseeable in light of Defendant’s knowledge of the icy condition and the common risk of slips and falls arising from untreated snow and ice on pedestrian pathways in winter.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.support_reasoning: The case concerns negligent storage of firearms and the foreseeability of harm from criminal misuse of guns by a person with violent and unstable history, not premises liability or icy winter conditions. Its foreseeability analysis is tied to guns as dangerous instrumentalities and the risk of theft and violent crime, not the commonplace risk of slip-and-fall on untreated snow and ice. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition about foreseeability of slip-and-fall harm from icy pedestrian pathways.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.relevant_excerpt: “A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor. … Consequently, with some important exceptions, ‘a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous.’ … In the instant case, Jupin argues that the theft of the handgun by Jason, and its subsequent use in the killing of a police officer, was a foreseeable consequence of Kask’s not ensuring the proper storage of firearms kept on her property, and that Kask thus owed the officer a duty of reasonable care. We agree … .”
